time_to_detect.description:
The amount of time in seconds to detect the incident.
Equals the difference between `customer_impact_start` and `detected`.

time_to_internal_response.description: The amount of time in seconds to call incident after detection. Equals the difference of `detected` and `created`.

time_to_repair.description: The amount of time in seconds to resolve customer impact after detecting the issue. Equals the difference between `customer_impact_end` and `detected`.

time_to_resolve.description: The amount of time in seconds to resolve the incident after it was created. Equals the difference between `created` and `resolved`.

Log.description: Object description of a log after being processed and stored by Datadog.

attributes.description: JSON object containing all log attributes and their associated values.
JSON object of attributes from your log.

host.description: Name of the machine from where the logs are being sent.

message.description:
The message [reserved attribute](https://docs.datadoghq.com/logs/log_collection/#reserved-attributes)
of your log. By default, Datadog ingests the value of the message attribute as the body of the log entry.
That value is then highlighted and displayed in the Logstream, where it is indexed for full text search.

service.description:
The name of the application or service generating the log events.
It is used to switch from Logs to APM, so make sure you define the same
value when you use both products.

status.description: Status of the message associated with your log.

tags.description: Array of tags associated with your log.

computes.description: A map of the metric name -> value for regular compute or list of values for a timeseries

LogsAggregateRequest.description: The object sent with the request to retrieve a list of logs from your organization.

compute.description: The list of metrics or timeseries to compute for the retrieved buckets.

items.description: A compute rule to compute metrics or timeseries

interval.description:
The time buckets' size (only used for type=timeseries)
Defaults to a resolution of 150 points

filter.description: The search and filter query settings

from.description: The minimum time for the requested logs, supports date math and regular timestamps

indexes.description: For customers with multiple indexes, the indexes to search. Defaults to ['*'] which means all indexes.

items.description: The name of a log index.

query.description: The search query - following the log search syntax.

to.description: The maximum time for the requested logs, supports date math and regular timestamps

group_by.description: The rules for the group by

facet.description: The name of the facet to use (required)

histogram.description:
Used to perform a histogram computation (only for measure facets).
Note: At most 100 buckets are allowed, the number of buckets is (max - min)/interval.

interval.description: The bin size of the histogram buckets

max.description:
The maximum value for the measure used in the histogram
(values greater than this one are filtered out)

min.description:
The minimum value for the measure used in the histogram
(values smaller than this one are filtered out)

limit.description: The maximum buckets to return for this group by

missing.description: The value to use for logs that don't have the facet used to group by

oneOf.description: The missing value to use if there is string valued facet.
The missing value to use if there is a number valued facet.

metric.description: The metric to sort by (only used for `type=measure`)

order.description: The order to use, ascending or descending

total.description: A resulting object to put the given computes in over all the matching records.

oneOf.description: If set to true, creates an additional bucket labeled "$facet_total"
A string to use as the key value for the total bucket
A number to use as the key value for the total bucket

options.description:
Global query options that are used during the query.
Note: You should only supply timezone or time offset but not both otherwise the query will fail.

timeOffset.description: The time offset (in seconds) to apply to the query.

timezone.description: The timezone can be specified both as an offset, for example: "UTC+03:00".

cursor.description: The returned paging point to use to get the next results

after.description:
The cursor to use to get the next results, if any. To make the next request, use the same.
parameters with the addition of the `page[cursor]`.

A list of warnings (non fatal errors) encountered, partial results might be returned if

facet.description: The name of the facet to use (required)

histogram.description:
Used to perform a histogram computation (only for measure facets).
Note: At most 100 buckets are allowed, the number of buckets is (max - min)/interval.

interval.description: The bin size of the histogram buckets

max.description:
The maximum value for the measure used in the histogram
(values greater than this one are filtered out)

min.description:
The minimum value for the measure used in the histogram
(values smaller than this one are filtered out)

limit.description: The maximum buckets to return for this group by

missing.description: The value to use for logs that don't have the facet used to group by

oneOf.description: The missing value to use if there is string valued facet.

metric.description: The metric to sort by (only used for `type=measure`)

order.description: The order to use, ascending or descending

total.description: A resulting object to put the given computes in over all the matching records.

A string to use as the key value for the total bucket
A number to use as the key value for the total bucket

JSON object of attributes from your log.

message.description:
The message [reserved attribute](https://docs.datadoghq.com/logs/log_collection/#reserved-attributes)
of your log. By default, Datadog ingests the value of the message attribute as the body of the log entry.
That value is then highlighted and displayed in the Logstream, where it is indexed for full text search.

service.description:
The name of the application or service generating the log events.
It is used to switch from Logs to APM, so make sure you define the same
value when you use both products.

status.description: Status of the message associated with your log.

tags.description: Array of tags associated with your log.

Link for the next set of results. Note that the request can also be made using the
POST endpoint.

after.description:
The cursor to use to get the next results, if any. To make the next request, use the same.
parameters with the addition of the `page[cursor]`.

A time window is specified to match when at least one of the cases matches true. This is a sliding window
and evaluates in real time.

keepAlive.description:
Once a signal is generated, the signal will remain open if a case is matched at least once within
this keep alive window.

maxSignalDuration.description:
A signal will close regardless of the query being matched once the time exceeds the maximum duration.
This time is calculated from the first seen timestamp.

forgetAfter.description: The duration in days after which a learned value is forgotten.

learningDuration.description:
The duration in days during which values are learned, and after which signals will be generated for values that
weren't learned. If set to 0, a signal will be generated for all new values after the first value is learned.

schema.description: Response with a list of incidents.

attributes.description: The incident's attributes from a response.

created.description: Timestamp when the incident was created.

customer_impact_duration.description:
Length of the incident's customer impact in seconds.
Equals the difference between `customer_impact_start` and `customer_impact_end`.

customer_impact_end.description: Timestamp when customers were no longer impacted by the incident.

customer_impact_scope.description: A summary of the impact customers experienced during the incident.

customer_impact_start.description: Timestamp when customers began being impacted by the incident.

customer_impacted.description: A flag indicating whether the incident caused customer impact.

detected.description: Timestamp when the incident was detected.

additionalProperties.description: Dynamic fields for which selections can be made, with field names as keys.

oneOf.description: A field with a single value selected.

type.description: Type of the single value field definitions.

value.description: The single value selected for this field.

oneOf.description: A field with potentially multiple values selected.

type.description: Type of the single value field definitions.

value.description: The multiple values selected for this field.

items.description: A value which has been selected for the parent field.

fields.description: A condensed view of the user-defined fields attached to incidents.

modified.description: Timestamp when the incident was last modified.

notification_handles.description: Notification handles that will be notified of the incident during update.

items.description: A notification handle that will be notified during incident update.

postmortem_id.description: The UUID of the postmortem object attached to the incident.

public_id.description: The monotonically increasing integer ID for the incident.

resolved.description: Timestamp when the incident's state was set to resolved.

time_to_detect.description:
The amount of time in seconds to detect the incident.
Equals the difference between `customer_impact_start` and `detected`.

time_to_internal_response.description: The amount of time in seconds to call incident after detection. Equals the difference of `detected` and `created`.

time_to_repair.description: The amount of time in seconds to resolve customer impact after detecting the issue. Equals the difference between `customer_impact_end` and `detected`.

time_to_resolve.description: The amount of time in seconds to resolve the incident after it was created. Equals the difference between `created` and `resolved`.

title.description: The title of the incident, which summarizes what happened.

relationships.description: The incident's relationships from a response.

post.description: The API endpoint to aggregate events into buckets and compute metrics and timeseries.

schema.description: The object sent with the request to retrieve a list of logs from your organization.

compute.description: The list of metrics or timeseries to compute for the retrieved buckets.

items.description: A compute rule to compute metrics or timeseries

interval.description:
The time buckets' size (only used for type=timeseries)
Defaults to a resolution of 150 points

filter.description: The search and filter query settings

from.description: The minimum time for the requested logs, supports date math and regular timestamps

indexes.description: For customers with multiple indexes, the indexes to search. Defaults to ['*'] which means all indexes.

items.description: The name of a log index.

query.description: The search query - following the log search syntax.

to.description: The maximum time for the requested logs, supports date math and regular timestamps

group_by.description: The rules for the group by

facet.description: The name of the facet to use (required)

histogram.description:
Used to perform a histogram computation (only for measure facets).
Note: At most 100 buckets are allowed, the number of buckets is (max - min)/interval.

interval.description: The bin size of the histogram buckets

max.description:
The maximum value for the measure used in the histogram
(values greater than this one are filtered out)

min.description:
The minimum value for the measure used in the histogram
(values smaller than this one are filtered out)

limit.description: The maximum buckets to return for this group by

missing.description: The value to use for logs that don't have the facet used to group by

oneOf.description: The missing value to use if there is string valued facet.

get.description:
List endpoint returns logs that match a log search query.
[Results are paginated][1].

Use this endpoint to see your latest logs.

**If you are considering archiving logs for your organization,
consider use of the Datadog archive capabilities instead of the log list API.
See [Datadog Logs Archive documentation][2].**

[1]: /logs/guide/collect-multiple-logs-with-pagination
[2]: https://docs.datadoghq.com/logs/archives

parameters.description: Search query following logs syntax.
parameters.name: filter[query]

parameters.description:
For customers with multiple indexes, the indexes to search
Defaults to '*' which means all indexes

parameters.name: filter[from]

parameters.description: Maximum timestamp for requested logs.
parameters.name: filter[to]

parameters.description: Order of logs in results.
parameters.name: sort

parameters.name: page[cursor]

parameters.name: page[limit]

schema.description: Response object with all logs matching the request and pagination information.

data.description: Array of logs matching the request.

items.description: Object description of a log after being processed and stored by Datadog.

attributes.description: JSON object containing all log attributes and their associated values.
JSON object of attributes from your log.

host.description: Name of the machine from where the logs are being sent.

message.description:
The message [reserved attribute](https://docs.datadoghq.com/logs/log_collection/#reserved-attributes)
of your log. By default, Datadog ingests the value of the message attribute as the body of the log entry.
That value is then highlighted and displayed in the Logstream, where it is indexed for full text search.

service.description:
The name of the application or service generating the log events.
It is used to switch from Logs to APM, so make sure you define the same
value when you use both products.

status.description: Status of the message associated with your log.

tags.description: Array of tags associated with your log.

next.description:
Link for the next set of results. Note that the request can also be made using the
POST endpoint.

after.description:
The cursor to use to get the next results, if any. To make the next request, use the same.
parameters with the addition of the `page[cursor]`.

A list of warnings (non fatal errors) encountered, partial results might be returned if

get.description:
Returns all configured count/gauge/rate/distribution metric names
(with additional filters if specified).

parameters.description: Filter metrics that have configured tags.
parameters.name: filter[configured]

parameters.description: Filter tag configurations by configured tags.
parameters.name: filter[tags_configured]

parameters.description: Filter tag configurations by metric type.
parameters.name: filter[metric_type]

parameters.description:
Filter distributions with additional percentile
aggregations enabled or disabled.
parameters.name: filter[include_percentiles]

parameters.description:
Filter metrics that have been submitted with the given tags. Supports boolean and wildcard expressions.
Cannot be combined with other filters.
parameters.name: filter[tags]

parameters.description:
The number of seconds of look back (from now) to apply to a filter[tag] query.
Defaults value is 3600 (1 hour), maximum value is 172,800 (2 days).
parameters.name: window[seconds]

schema.description: Response object that includes metrics and metric tag configurations.

data.description: Array of metrics and metric tag configurations.

items.description: Object for a metrics and metric tag configurations.

oneOf.description: Object for a single metric tag configuration.

id.description: The metric name for this resource.

oneOf.description: Object for a single metric tag configuration.

attributes.description: Object containing the definition of a metric tag configuration attributes.

created_at.description: Timestamp when the tag configuration was created.

include_percentiles.description:
Toggle to turn on/off percentile aggregations for distribution metrics.
Only present when the `metric_type` is `distribution`.

modified_at.description: Timestamp when the tag configuration was last modified.

tags.description: List of tag keys on which to group.

id.description: The metric name for this resource.

type.description: The metric tag configuration resource type.

get.description:
View distinct metrics volumes for the given metric name.

Custom distribution metrics will return both ingested and indexed custom metric volumes.
For Metrics without Limits™ beta customers, all metrics will return both ingested/indexed volumes.
Custom metrics generated in-app from other products will return `null` for ingested volumes.

parameters.description: The name of the metric.
parameters.name: metric_name

schema.description: Response object which includes a single metric's volume.

data.description: Possible response objects for a metric's volume.

oneOf.description: Object for a single metric's distinct volume.

attributes.description: Object containing the definition of a metric's distinct volume.

distinct_volume.description: Distinct volume for the given metric.

id.description: The metric name for this resource.

oneOf.description: Object for a single metric's ingested and indexed volume.

attributes.description: Object containing the definition of a metric's ingested and indexed volume.

indexed_volume.description: Indexed volume for the given metric.

ingested_volume.description: Ingested volume for the given metric.

id.description: The metric name for this resource.

type.description: The metric ingested and indexed volume type.

get.summary: List distinct metric volumes by metric name

get.description: Get all processes for your organization.

parameters.description: String to search processes by.
parameters.name: search

parameters.description: Comma-separated list of tags to filter processes by.
parameters.name: tags

parameters.description:
Unix timestamp (number of seconds since epoch) of the start of the query window.
If not provided, the start of the query window will be 15 minutes before the `to` timestamp. If neither
`from` nor `to` are provided, the query window will be `[now - 15m, now]`.
parameters.name: from

parameters.description:
Unix timestamp (number of seconds since epoch) of the end of the query window.
If not provided, the end of the query window will be 15 minutes after the `from` timestamp. If neither
`from` nor `to` are provided, the query window will be `[now - 15m, now]`.
parameters.name: to

parameters.description: Maximum number of results returned.
parameters.name: page[limit]

parameters.description:
String to query the next page of results.
This key is provided with each valid response from the API in `meta.page.after`.
parameters.name: page[cursor]

attributes.description: Attributes for a process summary.

tags.description: List of tags associated with the process.

items.description: A tag associated with the process.

meta.description: Response metadata object.

after.description:
The cursor used to get the next results, if any. To make the next request, use the same
parameters with the addition of the `page[cursor]`.

get.description: List rules.

parameters.description: Size for a given page.
parameters.name: page[size]

parameters.description: Specific page number to return.
parameters.name: page[number]

condition.description:
A rule case contains logical operations (`>`,`>=`, `&&`, `||`) to determine if a signal should be generated
based on the event counts in the previously defined queries.

notifications.description: Notification targets for each rule case.

createdAt.description: When the rule was created, timestamp in milliseconds.

creationAuthorId.description: User ID of the user who created the rule.

filters.description: Additional queries to filter matched events before they are processed.

query.description: Query for selecting logs to apply the filtering action.

isDefault.description: Whether the rule is included by default.

isDeleted.description: Whether the rule has been deleted.

evaluationWindow.description:
A time window is specified to match when at least one of the cases matches true. This is a sliding window
and evaluates in real time.

keepAlive.description:
Once a signal is generated, the signal will remain open if a case is matched at least once within
this keep alive window.

maxSignalDuration.description:
A signal will close regardless of the query being matched once the time exceeds the maximum duration.
This time is calculated from the first seen timestamp.

forgetAfter.description: The duration in days after which a learned value is forgotten.

learningDuration.description:
The duration in days during which values are learned, and after which signals will be generated for values that
weren't learned. If set to 0, a signal will be generated for all new values after the first value is learned.

queries.description: Queries for selecting logs which are part of the rule.

agentRuleId.description: The Agent rule ID. Must be unique within the rule.

expression.description:
A Runtime Security expression determines what activity should be collected by the Datadog Agent.
These logical expressions can use predefined operators and attributes. Tags cannot be used in Runtime
Security expressions. Instead, allow or deny based on tags under the advanced option.

distinctFields.description: Field for which the cardinality is measured. Sent as an array.

metric.description:
The target field to aggregate over when using the sum or max
aggregations.

query.description: Query to run on logs.

tags.description: Tags for generated signals.

meta.description: Object describing meta attributes of response.

total_filtered_count.description: Total count of elements matched by the filter.

tags.description:
**Note: This endpoint is in public beta. If you have any feedback, contact [Datadog support](https://docs.datadoghq.com/help/).**

To grant read access on log data at all, you must grant the `logs_read_data` permission.
From there you can limit what data a role grants read access to by associating a Restriction Query with that role.

A Restriction Query is a logs query that restricts which logs the `logs_read_data` permission grants read access to.
For users whose roles have Restriction Queries, any log query they make only returns those log events that also match
one of their Restriction Queries. This is true whether the user queries log events from any log-related feature, including
the log explorer, Live Tail, re-hydration, or a dashboard widget.

Restriction Queries currently only support use of the following components of log events:

- Reserved attributes
- The log message
- Tags

The recommended way to manage restricted read access on log data for customers with large or complicated organizational structures
is to add a team tag to log events to indicate which team(s) own(s) them, and then to scope Restriction Queries to the appropriate
values of the team tag. Tags can be applied to log events in many ways, and a log event can have multiple tags with the same key (like team)
and different valuesin this way the same log event can be visible to roles whose restriction queries are scoped to different team values.

You need an API and application key with Admin rights to interact with this endpoint.
tags.name: Logs Restriction Queries

tags.description:
The metrics endpoint allows you to:

- Post metrics data so it can be graphed on Datadogs dashboards
- Query metrics from any time period
- Modify tag configurations for metrics
- View tags and volumes for metrics

**Note**: A graph can only contain a set number of points
and as the timeframe over which a metric is viewed increases,
aggregation between points occurs to stay below that set number.

The Post, Patch, and Delete `manage_tags` API methods can only be performed by
a user who has the `Manage Tags for Metrics` permission.
tags.name: Metrics

tags.description: The processes API allows you to query processes data for your organization.
tags.name: Processes

tags.description:
The Roles API is used to create and manage Datadog roles, what
[global permissions](https://docs.datadoghq.com/account_management/rbac/)
they grant, and which users belong to them.

Permissions related to specific account assets can be granted to roles
in the Datadog application without using this API. For example, granting
read access on a specific log index to a role can be done in Datadog from the
[Pipelines page](https://app.datadoghq.com/logs/pipelines).
tags.name: Roles

tags.description:
Detection rules for generating signals and listing of generated
signals.
tags.name: Security Monitoring

tags.name: Users
